The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients
Willy Grasset, MD, Numa Mercier, MD, PhD, Christophe Chaussard, MD, Eric Carpentier, MD, Stephen Aldridge, MD, PhD, Dominique Saragaglia, MD, PhD

1067-2516/$ see front matter � 2012 by the Americ doi:10.1053/j.jfas.2011.10.010

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t
Peroneal tendon pathology is rare, but is probably underestimated because it is frequently undiagnosed.
It should always be in the differential diagnosis of lateral ankle pain.
Surgical treatment of peroneal tendinopathy is indicated after failure of conservative measures.
The aim of this retrospective study is to evaluate the medium-term clinical results of 17 patients operated for peroneal tendinopathy without tendon subluxation.
A series of 17 patients composed of 7 women and 10 men with a mean age of 53.6 � 4.6 (range 45 to 60) years were reviewed.
The mean preoperative Kitaoka score was 46.7 � 17.1 (range 25 to 69) points.
All patients had radiological evaluation, which demonstrated hindfoot varus in 6 of the 17.
Surgical interventions comprised synovectomy, debridement, suture-tubularization, ﬁbrous resection, or tenodesis depending on the preoperative ﬁndings and also a valgus osteotomy (Dwyer) in 6 cases and ankle ligament reconstruction (modiﬁed Blanchet) in 1 case.
All patients were reviewed clinically with a mean follow-up of 4.3 � 3.8 years (range 16 months to 14 years).
Average time to return to sport was 8.5 � 10.4 months (range 3 months to 3 years).

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t
The mean time to return to work was 2.5 � 1.9 (range 0 to 6) months.
The mean postoperative Kitaoka score was 90.1 � 11 (range 64 to 100) points with a statistically signiﬁcant improvement to the preoperative score (p <.0001).
Sixteen patients were satisﬁed or very satisﬁed with their treatment (94.1%).
Surgical treatment of peroneal tendinopathy after failed conservative treatment leads to signiﬁcantly improved function.
It is a simple treatment to undertake, which gives a good outcome for both the patient and surgeon.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t
Originally described by Monteggia (1813), Meyers (1924), Jones conservative treatment that had failed (persistence of disabling pain, (1932) (1), Hackenbroch (1927), and Burman (1953) (2,3), the pathology of the peroneal tendons is a relatively uncommon disease but is probably underestimated because it is frequently undiagnosed.
It should be considered in the assessment of all patients presenting with lateral ankle pain, especially if there is a history of sprains, or symptoms of instability without objective clinical or radiological evidence of laxity.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t
The peroneal muscles are the main evertors of the foot and have a major role in the lateral stability of the ankle.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t
Several authors such as Krause and Brodsky (4), Redfern and Myerson (5), Saxena and Cassidy (6), and Wapner et al (7) have reported classiﬁcation systems or treatment algorithms.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t
Wewanted to evaluate the clinical beneﬁts of surgical treatment of peroneal tendon disorders for patients who had already received thopaedic Surgeon, Department noble South Teaching Hospital, set).
an College of Foot and Ankle Surgeon patient demand).
We identiﬁed 17 patients with peroneal tendinopathy who underwent surgical treatment.
The aim of this study was to retrospectively evaluate the medium-term clinical outcomes of this surgery.
Patients with tendon subluxation or ankle instability as a primary diagnosis were excluded from this study.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t > Patients and Methods
Patients who underwent surgical treatment for peroneal tendinopathy, from January 1997 to December 2009, were identiﬁed in the authors’ practices, using procedure and diagnosis code numbers.
Onset of symptoms, represented by moderate or severe pain (16 cases) and/or instability (15 cases) was at least 3 months.
All patients had received medical treatment that had failed.
Conservative treatment in all cases consisted of medication (painkillers and nonsteroidal anti-inﬂammatory drugs) along with physiotherapy.
Reduction of recreational activities and cessation of sports for at least 3 months were undertaken.
Many patients had already seen their general medical practitioner, who had often misdiagnosed their symptoms as an ankle sprain; and so 5 had been immobilized in a plaster for 1 month, which had not improved the symptoms.
None had a history of traumatic fracture and 1 patient had a history of residual sprain with objective laxity (instability with objective laxity associated with a painful retromalleolar component).

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t > Patients and Methods
All cases had radiological imaging preoperatively.
There were 2 ultrasound examinations,15magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans, and 2 computed tomography (CT) s. All rights reserved.

 | foot varus averaging 4.6� � 1.5� (range 3� to 7�). One patient had a lateral ankle laxity associated with tendinopathy, demonstrated by stress views.
 | Intraoperatively, we found 14 tendons with ﬁssuring of peroneus brevis alone, 2 with ﬁssuring of peroneus brevis and longus together and 1 rupture of both tendons. Data such as age, sex, side of injury, diagnosis and treatment, postoperative complications, time to return to sports, and time off work were collated (Table 1).
 | The surgery undertaken was as follows: 17 synovectomies, 11 isolated peroneus | brevis sutures, 2 sutures of both peroneus longus and brevis, 3 tenodesis of brevis | to longus, and a Bosworth-type reverse plasty of the brevis around both peroneal | tendons. In 1 case, a frondiform ligament reconstruction (9) was undertaken, and in 6 | cases, a Dwyer-type osteotomy (10) in association with the peroneal tendon surgery | through the same incision was undertaken, which was extended distally and secured | The surgical technique used was similar to that of Krause and Brodsky (4) (Figs. 2 through 7). The patient is placed to expose the posterior-lateral ankle with a tourniquet around the thigh. A curved incision is made, from 5 cm proximal to the tip of the lateral malleolus and down about 2 cm distal, allowing possible distal extension if a Dwyer’s osteotomy is to be performed. The sural nerve is identiﬁed and preserved. The retinaculum is incised 5 mm posterior to the ﬁbula. The tendons are examined, including their deep surface. If themuscle belly of peroneus brevis descends very distally or if there is a peroneus quartus, these muscle bellies are excised. Debridement is done by performing a peri- tendinous synovectomy.

Debridement is done by performing a peri- tendinous synovectomy. Simple tendinopathy is treated by excision or resection of the ﬁbrosis. A ﬁssure is treated either by suture-tubularization or by tenodesis. The retinaculum is then repaired to prevent secondary dislocation stitching with a mono- ﬁlament absorbable suture to prevent adhesions. After skin closure, the ankle is immobilized with a cast for 15 days non–weight-bearing, then weight-bearing for 4 weeks before removing the cast and starting rehabilitation aimed at recovering range of movement and proprioceptive rehabilitation. with a 2-hole 1/3 tubular plate that did not irritate the patient.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t > Table 1 > Clinical Review
All patients were reviewed by an independent operator.
As in the preoperative assessment, evaluation of the outcome was made using the Kitaoka score (8) as an objective measure and by the patient’s satisfaction as a subjective measure.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > a b s t r a c t > Table 1 > Statistical Methods
The Student’s paired t test was used to compare the preoperative and postoperative Kitaoka scores, with 95% statistical signiﬁcance.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Results
The series consisted of 17 patients, 7 women and 10 men with a mean age of 53.6 � 4.6 (range 45 to 60) years operated on for peroneal tendinopathy from January 1997 to December 2009.
There were 10 right sides and 7 left sides.
Of the 17 operations, there were no local complications, but 1 patient had a deep vein thrombosis complicated by pulmonary embolism with no long-term sequelae.
Therewere no reoperations.
No patient required removal of hardware.
The mean follow-up was 4.3 � 3.8 years (range 16 months to 14 years).

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Results
The mean time to resumption of sports was 8.5 � 10.4 months (3 months to 3 years) and themean time off work was 2.5�1.9 (range to 6) months.
We could not meaningfully compare the time to return to work between patients who underwent osteotomy and those who did not because this series is too small.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Results
Preoperative Kitaoka scores (8) averaged 46.7 � 17.1 (range 25 to 69) points, with an average score of 11.5 for pain and 1.8 for instability.
Themean postoperative Kitaoka scorewas 90.1�11 (64 to 100) points with a mean pain score of 34.6/40 and stability score of 8/8, which gave a statistically signiﬁcant improvement from the preoperative score (p <.0001).
From a subjective point of view, 16 patients were satisﬁed or very satisﬁed with care (94.1%); only 1 was disappointed (5.9%).

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
We have shown that surgical treatment of peroneal tendinopathy after failure of conservative treatment provides a statistically signiﬁcant functional improvement.
Resumption of sports is relatively fast, although our patients were only practicing at a recreational level.
However, this delay is longer than that described by Saxena and Cassidy (6), and we believe that this is mainly due to the fact that our patients were, on average, older.
The time off work is relatively short and should not deter surgical treatment.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
The diagnosis is easily revealed with clinical examination, but most patients will require additional imaging to conﬁrm the diagnosis.
We requested an ultrasound combined with other imaging in cases.
This investigation, although operator-dependent, is inexpensive and can reveal the diagnosis if other examinations are not available and so is increasingly being used.
Although described as a subjective imaging modality, radiologists undertaking ultrasound imaging who are properly trained in this investigation for peroneal tendinopathy provide a less subjective interpretation.
The presence of a peritendinous effusion suggests ongoing tendon damage.
Grant and colleagues (11), in a series of 58 patients, reported a sensitivity of

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
Fig. 8. MRI showing a peroneus brevis ﬁssure with peroneus longus incarceration.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
100%, a speciﬁcity of 85%, and an accuracy of 90% for the diagnosis of peroneal tendinopathy.
In a prospective study comparing ultrasound and MRI, Rockett and coworkers (12) reported that ultrasound has a sensitivity of 100%, a speciﬁcity of 90%, and an accuracy of 94%, whereas MRI has a sensitivity of 23%, a speciﬁcity of 100%, and an accuracy of 66%.
We requested an MRI in 15 of our patients, which for us was the investigation of choice (Fig. 8).
It allows the diagnosis of tendinopathy if intratendonous high signal is seen on T2.
If there is mixed signal (loss of homogeneity), then intraosseous edema, or a circumferential peritendinous effusion (13) should be considered.
However, the diagnosis may be difﬁcult because asymptomatic patients can have a peritendinous effusion (14).
On the other hand, a study has described a correlation between MRI diagnosis and surgical tendon pathologies of the foot and ankle, ﬁnding a sensitivity of 83% for the diagnosis of tendinopathy for all tendons (Achilles, posterior tibial, etc.), but only 57% for peroneus longus and brevis (15).
Thus, in cases of negative MRI scan in the face of a good clinical examination, an ultrasound may be required for the ﬁnal therapeutic decision.
Finally, MRI may also be useful for ﬁnding a tendon abnormality, such as the presence of a peroneus quartus (16) or an unusually distal muscle belly of the peroneus brevis (17).

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
One patient had a CT scan as the only radiological investigation.
This was the ﬁrst patient in the series who had a request for a CT tenosynogram that was not undertaken because of local inﬂammation.
This is not a test that we recommend as ﬁrst line.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
More than 90% of our patients were satisﬁed or very satisﬁed, mostly because of the cessation of pain and a reduced sensation of instability, which had been very debilitating.
Indeed, all of our patients with preoperative symptoms of instability had no postoperative instability symptoms.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
Bonnin et al (18) described failure of lateral ligament reconstruction for chronic ankle laxity as a result of coexistent peroneal tendon injury, suggesting a sprain-tendinopathy link.
This concept has also been demonstrated by Gray and Alpar (19).
Thus, laxity and instability must be well understood.
Indeed, ankle laxity may be responsible for peroneal tendinopathy, itself giving rise to symptoms of superimposed instability.
We found this association in 1 case (proven laxity with tendinopathy, patient 5).
The feeling of instability should always be proven by laxity on clinical examination, which speciﬁcally needs to bemanaged by a ligament reconstruction.
In contrast, the sensation of instability caused by peroneal tendon injury can only be alleviated by tendon repair.
We do not recommend, however, systematically addressing the peroneal sheath during ligament reconstruction surgery for chronic laxity, without clinical reason.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
On the other hand, like Krause and Brodsky (4) or Sobel and colleagues (20), we believe that the pathology can arise as a result of axial malalignment but systemic causes should still be ruled out.
In the literature, differentiation between lesions induced by trauma (chronic instability of the ankle) and degenerative changes without preceding trauma cannot be found.
There is no agreement about the underlying etiology.
Petersen et al attribute poor healing and tendinopathy to areas of hypovascularization within the peroneal tendons (21), whereas Sobel and coworkers showed sufﬁcient vascularization in a cadaveric study (22).

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
We believe that degenerative tendinopathy should be deﬁned because the etiology and prognosis are probably different.
Early in our experience, wewere skeptical about the healing of tendons sutured in the presence of poor vascularization.
In hindsight, the results of suturing have been encouraging, although there is no deﬁnite evidence of healing.
In the future, it might be interesting to have routine ultrasound preoperatively and postoperatively to assess the healing.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
Brandes and Smith (23) reported the presence of hindfoot varus in 82% of patients treated for tendinopathy of peroneus longus.
We considered the hindfoot to be varus if there was an angle of less than 4� valgus on a Meary radiograph (angle formed perpendicular to the line formed along the plantar surface during weight-bearing, and the line formed between the center of the talar dome and the center of the plantar surface).
Thus, in 35% of cases we performed a posterior realignment with a Dwyer’s osteotomy (10) (varus between 3 and 7), believing that the hindfoot varus was the cause of tendon injury.
This osteotomy is widely practiced in the literature.
No patient required removal of hardware because the ﬁxation material was thin, and so does not cause irritation of the peroneal tendons and is not uncomfortable for the patient.
All these patients are doing well, but it is unclear if the osteotomy was a necessary treatment for the tendon injury.
To prove this would probably require a prospective randomized study, but given the small numbers, it would be extremely difﬁcult to carry out such a study.
We were unable to ﬁnd any studies indicating the outcome of such treatment associated with the management of the peroneal tendinopathy.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
Redfern and Myerson (5) have developed a treatment algorithm according to intraoperative ﬁndings.
If the tendons are largely intact, the longitudinal ﬁssure is excised and the tendon tubularized.
If one tendon is irreparable and the other is functional, a tenodesis is performedbetween the2 tendons at theproximal portionof the rupture.
If both tendons are not functional, then reconstruction is indicated.
If the course of the tendon is acceptable and the proximalmusculotendinous junction is not too damaged,1-stage repair is donewith a tendon graft.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
For lesions with longstanding scar formation in the tendon bed, ﬁrststage reconstruction with Hunter rods is required before deﬁnitive tendon graft.
In cases of minimal tendon excursion, tendon graft is unlikely to be effective and tendon transfer is therefore performed.
The ﬂexor digitorum longus is used because its course and strength are similar to those of the peroneus brevis.
Redfern and Myerson report a series of 28 patients treated by this algorithm and found a postoperative AmericanOrthopaedic Foot andAnkle Society (AOFAS) score of 82 associated with a disappearance of instability in all cases.

The Surgical Treatment of Peroneal Tendinopathy (Excluding Subluxations): A Series of 17 Patients > Discussion
Our ﬁndings support those of Krause and Brodsky (4), who reported a series of 20 patients treated surgically for tendinopathy of peroneus brevis ﬁssuring with a mean postoperative AOFAS score of 85.
They suggest that lesions representing less than 50% of the surface of the tendon were treated by excision of the crack followed by a tubularization, and those above 50% by tenodesis.
With a similar technique, Saxena and Cassidy (6) reported a series of 41 patients with a preoperative AOFAS score average of 52 � 16.8, a mean postoperative score of 89.7 � 10.3, and a statistically signiﬁcant improvement (p <.0001).
Wapner et al (7) reported a series of 7 patients treated for chronic peroneal ﬁssuring using Hunter rods and transfer of the ﬂexor hallucis, with review at an average of 8.5 years.
Six of 7 patients had a complete cessation of pain.
Our functional results are comparable with those in the literature, with an easily reproducible technique, although the functional assessment scores used are not exactly the same.
Regarding this technique, note that we have found no requirement for using anchors to reinforce the repair of the retinaculum because it has been good, strong quality tissue in all cases and so a single suture was sufﬁcient.
Thus, we are convinced that peroneal tendinopathy is amenable to surgical treatment.
It must be noted that all of the patients who underwent surgery presented with ﬁssuring lesions of the tendons.
In such cases, cast immobilization has been ineffective: the ﬁssuring is unable to heal by itself.
In our experience those lesions without ﬁssuring are best treated with physiotherapy.
Van Dijk and Kort (24) have described tendinoscopy for peroneal tendinopathy.
They described the beneﬁt of this treatment for stenosing tenosynovitis, or posttraumatic adhesions, in terms of postoperative follow-up.
However, we have found it difﬁcult to use this technique alone to perform suturing of the tendons without further incisions, and so we feel an open approach is the best solution for our patients.
In conclusion, peroneal tendinopathy is a relatively rare condition but is certainly underdiagnosed.
Early treatment can only be considered if the diagnosis is suggested by a careful history and clinical examination.
MRI is the investigation of choice to conﬁrm such pathology, but ultrasound in expert hands should not be dismissed.
We believe that surgical treatment provides signiﬁcant beneﬁt to quality of life when medical treatment has not been effective or functional.
However, recommendations about the choice of the various surgical procedures to be undertaken for different lesionsmay be necessary and should be based on studies with high levels of evidence.
Prospective, randomized, controlled studies will be difﬁcult to undertake, however.
